stories.story: I remember this one timber frame raising, must’ve been ten, fifteen years ago. The sky was gray, cool air. The crew was sharp, moving on my calls—‘Up slow,’ ‘Hold.’ After every pin was set, I had them recheck for plumb. I always taught the young guys that small mistakes early become big problems later. We found a crowned sill, and instead of forcing the post, we took the time to plane it down. It’s about respecting the material, not fighting it. When that bent finally settled into place, you could feel the vibration through the whole frame. A solid, satisfying thud. That’s the feeling of a job done right. Disciplined craft, that’s what it is. A good day's work.

You know, I was thinking about a frame raising from a while back. It was a cool day. We were lifting the bents, and I was calling out the moves. ‘Up slow,’ ‘Hold.’ I made sure we checked for plumb after every pin. I always told my crew, you can't ignore the small stuff. We had a sill that was crowned, so we planed it down. You gotta work with the wood. I remember the feeling when the frame settled. A solid thud. It’s a good feeling, knowing it’s right. It’s about... uh... doing things the right way, with patience. Yeah, a good day.

It means the work is good. It’s... it’s about discipline. Mm... a good memory.
